item.content:encoded:
As for myself, I gladly confess that the highest compliment that could be paid to me as a Christian philosopher, apologist, and theologian is to call me “Thomistic.” This, of course, does not mean I accept everything Aquinas wrote naively and uncritically. It does mean that I believe he was one of the greatest systematic minds the christian church has ever had, and that I can see a lot farther standing on his shoulders than by attacking him in the back. No, I do not agree with everything he ever wrote. On the other hand, neither do I agree with everything I ever wrote. But seven hundred years from now no one will even recognize my name, while Aquinas’s works will still be used with great profit.

—Norman L. Geisler, Thomas Aquinas: An Evangelical Appraisal (Grand Rapids: Baker, 1991), 14.

item.content:encoded:
The 2014 rendition of Ravi Zacharias International Ministries’ Summit on Islam is a one-day seminar in Atlanta on January 11th: “Understanding and Answering Islam.” Having attended last year’s Summit in Orlando, I can say that, if you are looking for a thoughtful, entry-level introduction to American Evangelical thought on Islam, this will be a great event for you to get your toes wet in the ocean of Islam.

If you already have your toes in the water—e.g., you have already starting frequenting your local mosque and have initiated friendships with local Muslims—you might want to invest in a more advanced seminar such as the annual Dearborn Legacy Conference.

item.content:encoded:
Willem J. de Wit writes a helpful introduction to Wageeh Y. F. Mikhail’s recent dissertation at the University of Birmingham on a forgotten ninth-century Christian theologian who lived in an Islamic context: ‘Ammār al-Baṣrī’s Kitāb al-Burhān: a topical and theological analysis of Arabic Christian theology in the ninth century (PDF; 445 pp.; 2 MB). This welcome study includes the first English translation of ‘Ammār’s Kitāb al-Burhān.

In class last fall I tried to emphasize the need for us Western Christians to listen to and learn from our Eastern adelphoi with respect to Christian-Muslim relations. Mikhail’s study looks to be an important and much useful tool for this purpose. Along this line de Wit asks, in reference to ‘Ammār’s Christian musing on Islam: “could it be that, at least in some respects, the Arabs are centuries ahead of Europeans and Americans?” I hope we Western Evangelicals are ready with a quick “yes!”
